title: fix: sanitize HTML from Mastodon servers by jviide · Pull Request #788 · elk-zone/elk

last_post.content:
Elk, the Mastodon client built in the open, looks and feels great. Check it out at @elk.

It's so nice I also want to use it. So I recently took a look at the code and opened some pull requests dealing fixing some security issues:

Sanitize HTML from Mastodon servers: https://github.com/elk-zone/elk/pull/788
Prevent HTML injections to code blocks: https://github.com/elk-zone/elk/pull/1165

Thanks to the crew (@antfu, @daniel, @sxzz, @patak et al.) for being super responsive and encouraging. They've dealt with the issues in an exemplary way, and gotten the patches out really fast.

Some technical background: The Mastodon API returns the post contents (among other things) as raw HTML. The default Mastodon server implementation does sanitize the HTML. But sometimes server-side sanitation lets things slip through, or the server itself could be in malicious hands.

If the client accepts the incoming raw HTML as-is, it can lead to Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities. Let's say a server returns a post with HTML content like <script>...</script>. If the client just trusts the server and injects that content to the page, the server can effectively execute arbitrary code in the client context - for example to steal the client's login information. Or to take over the whole page like in the attached demo video 🙂

Therefore, it's best to also sanitize the HTML on the client side. This can be tricky. Doubly so if the client wants implement features like rendering source code blocks with syntax highlighting, or turning Twitter mentions into links.

The linked pull requests fortify a couple of places where Elk prepares HTML content for display. I sincerely hope other people in the infosec scene find Elk's UI intriguing, maybe enough to even take a look at the code. It's a great chance to make a cool up-and-coming tool better!

#elk #vuejs #vue #xss

title: github.com/yairchu/awesome-str...

last_post.content:
Recent announcement of Project Mage inspired me to write a short tour around the current scene of #StructuralEditing - from my perspective, so I shall begin with the projects that resonate with me most strongly.

So, the number 1 is @leif 's work on "Interactive Visual Syntax", as explained here:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8htgAxJuK5c

(Leif also implemented this idea in the visr.pl online IDE)

Number 2 is @vez 's Polytope editor for JavaScript:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8g_XCZSY7lM

I was also hugely impressed with @disconcision 's Fructure, which - except just being a beautiful user experience also is a beautiful implementation:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CnbVCNIh1NA

Andy has since moved to other places, contributing to Cyrus Omar's hazel.org and David Moon's tylr.fun

Not long after releasing my first prototype of GRASP, I ran into Yasuyuki Maeda (who's Japanese, but happened to be touring around Europe at that time), who did this really amazing front-end for Clojure:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RuU0HI-paik

Within the same space, there's Ella Hoeppner's Vlojure for ClojureScript:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1OcAUhe3E1E

Katie Bell did a sort of similar work for Python that can be found at splootcode.io

@o_kryvonos living in Ukraine under russian fire managed to deliver Lisperanto:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QNyuMK8ZrHI

Among Ukrainian hackers, there's also Ivan Daniluk, who has some very interesting thoughts concerning "visual programming": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ps3mBPcjySE

And of course there's @jonathoda who - in addition to doing crazy experiments with his SubText (e.g. https://vimeo.com/451278506) has been doing wonderful stuff in bringing the community together with various workshops and other social initiatives.

Also, a lot of cool ideas can be found on "Emil's Programming Viz" vlog:

https://www.youtube.com/@emilsprogrammingviz1811

When it comes to visual thinking about computation, the ideas of @spiralganglion on the Hest programming environment are really outstanding, as is his conduction of the "Future of Coding" podcast (and taking @jimmyhmiller on board was certainly a great idea).

Yair Chuchem (and others) also did impressive work with the Lambdu programming environment, and Yair himself created this wonderful list of "awesome structure editors":
https://github.com/yairchu/awesome-structure-editors

If you feel that this list is incomplete or that your project (or some other important project) is missing from here, it's perhaps also because 2500 characters on this mastodon instance aren't all that much, but of course feel free to add replies to this toot.

title: github.com/web-platform-tests/...

last_post.content:
Did you know the #CSSWG extended the :nth-of-type/:nth-child selectors to be much more powerful?

Safari shipped support for these new superpowers in 2015! https://caniuse.com/css-nth-child-of

But none of the other browsers did… so you probably haven’t heard about it.

Then Apple proposed :nth-* pseudo-classes interoperability for Interop 2023: https://github.com/web-platform-tests/interop/issues/225

And now Chrome is working on implementing support! ☺️

@bramus wrote about what you can do with these CSS selectors:
https://www.bram.us/2020/03/16/css-nth-of-class-selector/

title: Moderation: Sharing the load, Sharing tickets, feedback and more. · Discussion #22979 · mastodon/mastodon

last_post.content:
Another server has your server blocked. You ask why. response?

"you should have blocked certain places by now but you haven't we don't trust you."

"we block as soon as we notice a problem, what are you suggesting?"

They refuse to tell us what we "should" have blocked or why.

There is no elegant way to find out a list of bad actors, no simple way to verify it.

I don't like just taking a block list on faith. That's what I want to address with this idea:

https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/discussions/22979

title: GitHub - natemoo-re/tiny-decode: Decode HTML entities the browser-friendly way

last_post.content:
I just published 🤏 `tiny-decode`!

Traditionally, decoding HTML named character references requires a large table to store entity names and the code points to which they refer. Unless you take extreme care, this data can easily end up in your JavaScript bundle.

Using export conditions, `tiny-decode` only includes a few bytes in your browser bundles. Server bundles include the full table as usual.

`entities` 👉 19.64 kB gzip
`tiny-decode` 👉 0.56 kB gzip

https://github.com/natemoo-re/tiny-decode

title: GitHub - freedmand/textra: A command-line application to convert images, PDFs, and audio files to text using Apple's APIs

last_post.content:
@siracusa @atpfm
Whisper relies on pytorch but can’t use the Metal version (MPS) so it is all cpu on a Mac.

My guess is they chose Whisper over Apple’s framework bc it’s more accurate & doesn’t require any changes to system settings to turn on. In my limited testing, Whisper is a bit more cpu intensive.

The utility textra can transcribe an mp3 file using Apple’s framework. https://github.com/freedmand/textra

I did a quick comparison and Apple’s framework is noticeably less accurate than whisper.

last_post.content: #emacs Book mode is an attempt at offering an interface for reading org-mode files with a clean layout. It is based on the use of large margins, headline and mode-line, with leading stars and bullets in the left margin using right alignment and different symbols. A map for code

In this video, I start up in quick succession:

* a simple test app
* the 'driver' programming environment showing the map for the app's code
* the 'meta-driver' programming environment showing the map for the driver's code

title: stdenv/linux/default.nix: add gcc rebuild during bootstrap by trofi · Pull Request #209063 · NixOS/nixpkgs

last_post.content:
Spent past few days exploring nixpkgs bootstrap process.

Did you know that your glibc package contains libgcc_s.so.1 from gcc-8 even if the rest of the system is built with gcc-11? Most of the time it does not matter. But sometimes it breaks in unusual ways.

Here is my attempt to fix it: https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/pull/209063

And a few words and pictures to explain how nixpkgs bootstrap is laid out and how I tried to fix it: https://trofi.github.io/posts/275-nixpkgs-bootstrap-deep-dive.html

title: To enhance privacy, reduce IP and Session retention from 1 year to 2 days by eobrain · Pull Request #22393 · mastodon/mastodon

last_post.content:
If anyone reading this has write access to the #Mastodon #GitHub repo, I'd appreciate a review to unblock this change:

https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/pull/22393

To improve #privacy, it reduces the default retention period of IP addresses from one year to two days.

Given that most admins are unlikely to change the default, this means that more visitors to Mastodon servers would be less vulnerable to their activity being tracked by government authorities.

title: GitHub - seanthegeek/mastodon-dmarc-survey: A survey of DMARC deployment across all domains hosting public a Mastodon instance

last_post.content:
In the short time I've been the #Mastodon #Fediverse so far, I've talked a lot about how #DMARC can help prevent #spoofed #emails from being delivered to their targets, in light of a wave of Mastodon-themed phishing. That made me wonder, "How many Mastodon instances have a DMARC record on their domain? How many of those are set up to properly?" For their own security Users should join servers with an enforced DMARC policy, and instance admins should enforce DMARC on their domains to protect users and attract a security conscious userbase.

I wrote a script that queries instances.social for the 1000 top Mastodon instances based on the number of active users, feeds that list to #checkdmarc to query for, parse, and validate DMARC #DNS records. Here are the results.

https://github.com/seanthegeek/mastodon-dmarc-survey

As of earlier today, 148 instances with a combined 295, 975 active users had an enforced DMARC policy (p=quarantine or p=reject). 113 instances with a combined 168,965 active users have deployed a monitor only policy, 3 instances with a combined 577 active users have an invalid DMARC record, and 113 instances with a combined 486,972 active users don't have any DMARC record.

As I looked through the list of instances, I noticed that infosec.exchange is now the 7th largest Mastodon instance on the public internet, with 18,328 active users (and counting. Thanks @jerry!

#Infosec #InformationSecuriy #phish #phishing #spoofing #adminsofmastodon #OpenSource #OpenSourceSoftware #FLOSS #Python #CLI #API
